longDescription: Yasakani no Magatama (ÂÖ´Â∞∫ÁìäÂãæÁéâ, 'Eight-Shaku Curved Jewel') is the sacred jewel and one of the Three Imperial Regalia of Japan. Magatama are comma-shaped or curved beads that have been found in Japan dating back to prehistoric times, often made of jade, agate, or quartz. The Yasakani no Magatama was created by the deity Tamanooya-no-Mikoto to help lure Amaterasu from the Heavenly Rock Cave. Along with the mirror, it was hung on the sacred sakaki tree outside the cave. The jewel represents benevolence and compassion, the third Imperial virtue alongside wisdom (mirror) and valor (sword). It was given to Ninigi when he descended from Takamagahara and has been passed down through the Imperial line. The jewel is currently kept in the Imperial Palace in Tokyo, in the Sword and Jewel Sanctuaries. Like the other regalia, it has never been publicly displayed, and its exact appearance, size, and material composition remain uncertain.

extendedContent.title: Description and Nature
extendedContent.content:
The Yasakani no Magatama is one of the three Imperial Regalia of Japan (Sanshu no Jingi),
                    along with the sacred mirror Yata no Kagami and the divine sword Kusanagi no Tsurugi. These
                    three treasures represent the legitimacy of the Japanese Imperial line, descended from the
                    sun goddess Amaterasu herself.
                
                
                    A magatama is a curved, comma-shaped bead with a hole at one end, a form found in Japanese
                    archaeology dating back thousands of years. The Yasakani no Magatama is believed to be made
                    of jade or a similar precious stone, though its exact appearance is unknown as it has never
                    been publicly displayed or photographed.

extendedContent.title: Mythological Origin
extendedContent.content:
The Cave of Amaterasu
                
                    According to the Kojiki and Nihon Shoki, the sacred jewel was created during the crisis
                    when Amaterasu, the sun goddess, withdrew into the Ama-no-Iwato cave after being offended
                    by her brother Susanoo's destructive behavior. With the sun hidden, the world fell into
                    darkness.
                
                
                    The other gods devised a plan to lure Amaterasu out. They hung the Yasakani no Magatama
                    and the Yata no Kagami on a sacred sakaki tree outside the cave, while the goddess Ame-no-Uzume
                    performed a ribald dance that caused the assembled deities to laugh uproariously.
                
                
                    Curious about the commotion, Amaterasu peered out, saw her beautiful reflection in the
                    mirror, and was drawn forth. Light returned to the world. The jewel and mirror that had
                    enticed her forth became sacred treasures.
                

                Descent to Earth
                
                    When Amaterasu sent her grandson Ninigi-no-Mikoto to pacify and rule the terrestrial realm,
                    she gave him the three sacred treasures as proof of his divine mandate. From Ninigi descended
                    the imperial line that continues to the present day, with the regalia serving as material
                    proof of the emperor's divine ancestry and legitimacy.

extendedContent.title: Historical Significance
extendedContent.content:
The Yasakani no Magatama is the only one of the three regalia kept in the Imperial Palace
                    rather than a Shinto shrine. It is traditionally used during the enthronement ceremony
                    (Sokui no rei) as one of the objects formally transferred to the new emperor.
                
                
                    Unlike the sword (which was legendarily lost at sea in 1185 during the Genpei War and
                    may have been replaced) and the mirror (which is kept at Ise), the magatama is believed
                    to be the original artifact from the age of the gods, never lost or destroyed throughout
                    Japan's turbulent history.

shortDescription: Sacred curved jewel representing benevolence, one of the Three Imperial Regalia of Japan

mythologyContexts.usage: The Yasakani no Magatama represents the virtue of benevolence and the Emperor's compassion for the people. Magatama jewels have been sacred in Japan since prehistoric times, possibly representing the human soul, the moon, or a fetus. The comma shape may symbolize the cycle of life and death, yin and yang, or the unity of heaven and earth. As one of the Three Sacred Treasures, it completes the trinity of Imperial virtues: wisdom (mirror), valor (sword), and benevolence (jewel).

mythologyContexts.symbolism: The magatama represents benevolence (‰ªÅ jin) and compassion, essential virtues for righteous rule. The curved shape has multiple symbolic interpretations: the soul's journey, the unity of opposites (yin-yang), fertility, or the moon. Some scholars suggest it represents a bear's fang or a fetal position, symbolizing life and protection. The jewel's material (possibly jade) connects to earth and longevity. The color green traditionally represents life, growth, and harmony with nature. As a necklace of multiple beads, it may represent the unity of many people under one ruler.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: Magatama jewels are iconic symbols of ancient Japan, found in archaeological sites across the archipelago. They were worn by rulers and buried with the elite, suggesting their connection to power and the afterlife. The Yasakani no Magatama's presence in the Imperial Palace makes it more accessible than the mirror (at Ise) but still hidden from public view. The jewel's mystery has led to various theories about its composition and appearance. Some sources suggest it might be a string of many magatama rather than a single jewel. The jewel inspires modern jewelry and appears frequently in Japanese art and popular culture.
